The remarks of the honourable member for Illawarra, the honourable member for Coolgardie, and the honourable member for Barrier, are extremely unjust, and show the basest ingratitude after the manner in which I supported them in connection with the exemption of vermin killers.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: Macquarie) The honourable member for Herbert, with obher honourable members, was, to a large extent, responsible for refrigerating machinery of all kinds being retained on the dutiable list. I do not know whether the honourable member voted against the proposal, but if he were in favour of it , it was unfortunate that he was not present in order to support us on the division. In view of the importance of placing all refrigerating machines on the freelist, the honourable member for Herbert would do well to press his amendment to a vote. If we secure the exemptions contemplated by him, there will be no just reason why we should not again 'test the feeling of the committee on the question of placing all refrigerating machines on the free list. I believe that on reconsideration of that matter we shall secure a majority of votes.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: The honourable member cannot discuss refrigerating machinery in connection with this amendment.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: " Freezing machinery used in meat works," is included in the amendment now before the committee. * The CH AIRMAN - The commitbee have already decided that refrigerating machinery should not be placed on the list of exemptions, and I am therefore of opinion that the honourable member for Herbert cannot include freezing machinery used in meat works in his amendment.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: When the committee were considering the question of placing refrigerating machinery on the free list, you decided that it would be competent' for honourable members to propose the exemption of any special refrigerators after the committee had declared against the general exemption. The exemption of dairying machinery was then proposed, and it would have been quite competent for any honourable member to afterwards move that meat freezing machinery be placed on the free list. To my mind, it is remarkable, in view of the decision given last evening, that any exception should now be taken to the course proposed by the honourable member for Herbert.

Speaker: Mr THOMSON
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: I should not have risen but for a remark which fell from the Minister for Trade and Customs. The right honourable gentleman asked whether the meat industry should be treated better than are other industries. I wish to point out to him that in .relieving these machines from taxation he is not benefiting those who are engaged in the meat industry-bh e canners or suppliers of frozen meat-bu the is benefiting the whole community. This industry has to compete in the markets of the world. It is threatened with extinction by the Argentine producers, and we know that recently in South Africa a difference of a very small sum turned the balance in regard to a contract for' a considerable quantity of meat against Australia. It is one of the most important industries in the community, and it benefits the whole of the continent. I know that some Australian meat works are not conducted upon strictly commercial principles. The Sydney Meat Works are an example of this. Those interested in that venture are concerned in the large producing interests of Australia, and their desire is to retain a market for their surplus stock, which otherwise would not be absorbed. They recognise that by securing such a market a benefit is conferred upon Australia and those engaged in our large producing interests, even though a loss is sometimes suffered. Consequently we should give that industry every opportunity for competing with the rest of the world. Under these circumstances, I hope bhat any honourable member who entertains the view that the action of the mover of this amendment is an inconsistent one, will not pause to consider that, but will support his proposal.

Speaker: Mr FULLER
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: I desire to move to add after the words "freezing machinery" the words " used in primary industries."

Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: I rise to a point of order. The committee have already decided that dairy refrigerators shall - he taxable, and under such circumstances I desire to know if the amendment is in order, seeing that dairying constitutes one of our primary industries.

Speaker: Mr FULLER
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING

Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING

Speaker: Mr EWING
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: The whole question turns upon whether dairying is a primary industry.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: ^Las t night the committee decided the question of whether refrigerating machinery should be included in the schedule of special exemptions. The honourable and learned member for Illawarra now wishes to add to " freezing machinery " the words " used in primary industries." Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: Macquarie) The best course for the honourable member for Herbert to take would be to propose his amendment in its original form. After that has been disposed of the whole question can be reviewed. I do not want to take this matter out of the hands of the honourable member, but a motion of this kind should be submitted. If the honourable member desires a clear vote on the question, in which I shall be glad to support him, it would be better to submit the amendment as originally drafted, dealing with freezing machinery used in meat works.

Speaker: Mr BAMFORD
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: It was the words "used in meat works," referring to canning machines, which I omitted from my amendment.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: The Chairman informed me that it would be out of order to insert refrigerating machinery, because there had been a decision on that matter. I understood, and I think the Chairman understood, that the honourable member had withdrawn the words referring to refrigerating machinery used in meat works, and there has clearly been a mistake. If that is so, it is quite competent for the committee to discuss the question whether freezing machinery used in meat works shall be put on the free list. This is a matter which is most important, and should receive point of further consideration, in view of the fact of the many difficulties that have to be contended with in the export of meat and dairy produce. The honourable member for Melbourne last night said that he was strongly in favour of the free admission of refrigerating machines connected with larger works, while he proposed that similar machines used for dairy purposes shall pay a duty, because the latter are being made by a few manufacturers in Melbourne. This is a question which affects all the primary producers of the Commonwealth. The honourable member for Melbourne was induced to alter his opinion only because of a telegram from some firm in Queensland to the effect that they were not manufacturing these articles, but only supplying them.

Speaker: Mr KINGSTON
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: That is not so ; I showed it was the other way.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: There are more rapid strides in improvements in connection with this class of machinery than in connection with any other; and I am surprised at the attitude of the honourable member for Melbourne. In many cases the machinery is patented, and cannot be manufactured here without permission, and to impose a duty would be to do an injury to that class on which we depend more than any other for the success of the Commonwealth. I shall vote for this amendment, in the hope that reconsideration will be given to other rejected proposals, and that we shall have the satisfaction, in view of the closeness of the division last night, of placing all refrigerating machinery on the free list.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: There is some difference between refrigerating machinery and freezing machinery. A chamber at 40 to 35 degrees would be called a refrigerator, but could not be called a freezing chamber, and the machinery and chemicals nsed in the processes must, I think, be different. Whether the distinction goes so far as to require any grave difference in the machinery, such as to justify separate names, I cannot altogether determine, but I think that there must be a great deal of difference in construction. Many firms in Australia can construct refrigerating machinery, but not many can construct the better classes of freezing machinery, because the demand for the latter is not sufficiently large.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: There is not slightest distinction; they both have the same trade name.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: MANUFACTURERS OF MINING
text: But surely there is a great difference between a freezing chamber and a refrigerating chamber? We know that some shipments of refrigerated meat were altQgether lost owing to the lowness of the temperature, which had to be altered ; and it is likely that there must be some considerable difference in the machinery used for this purpose.
